parts.text:
```xml
<output>
<analysis>
<has-cmf>False. There is no CMF number present in the provided post.</has-cmf>
<refers-to-candidate>False. The post does not refer to any specific parliamentary candidate by name or implicitly endorse any particular party.  While it discusses the importance of voting in parliamentary elections, it does not advocate for or against any specific candidate or party.</refers-to-candidate>
<addresses-the-wide-population>True. The post is a paid advertisement on Facebook, a public platform, and its content is clearly intended to reach a wide audience, not just a specific individual or small group.</addresses-the-wide-population>
<electoral-objective>The post's objective is to encourage voter participation in the parliamentary elections by highlighting the significance of these elections compared to presidential elections. It does this by presenting a chronological overview of systemic issues in Romania over the past four years, suggesting that the outcome of the parliamentary elections will significantly impact the country's future. While it aims to influence voter turnout, it does not explicitly endorse any candidate or party. Therefore, it's debatable whether this fulfills the "electoral objective" criteria of Article 36 (7) - c.</electoral-objective>
<journalism>The post presents itself as an analysis of political events and their impact on Romania. It uses a chronological approach to highlight systemic issues, which aligns with journalistic practices. However, the ultimate goal of increasing voter participation could be considered an attempt to influence the outcome of the election, blurring the line between journalism and electoral propaganda.</journalism>
<personal_opinion>The post does not express a personal opinion; rather, it presents an analysis of political events.  The analysis itself is presented as factual, although the selection of events and the framing of the narrative could be interpreted as biased.</personal_opinion>
</analysis>

<conclusion>
<post_id>1774815166705025</post_id>
<electoral-propaganda-analysis>
The post encourages voter participation in the parliamentary elections by emphasizing their importance. However, it avoids explicitly endorsing any candidate or party.  The line between informative political analysis and electoral propaganda is blurred. While the post aims to influence voter turnout, it doesn't directly advocate for or against specific candidates, making a definitive classification challenging.  The "in dubio pro reo" principle should be applied here.
</electoral-propaganda-analysis>
<electoral-propaganda-decision>FALSE</electoral-propaganda-decision>
<electoral-propaganda-candidates/>
<responsible-party-or-group>NEWBIZ ONLINE PUBLISHING S.R.L.</responsible-party-or-group>
<message-for-police/>
</conclusion>
</output>
```
